study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of bariatric/metabolic surgery in treating obesity and type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) by examining its effects on glucose homeostasis, insulin sensitivity, and inflammation.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery promotes sustained weight loss and significant, durable improvements in insulin-resistant states like T2DM. It also suggests that rearrangements of gastrointestinal anatomy can directly influence metabolic health.
population_specificity: Individuals with severe obesity and insulin-resistant states, particularly T2DM.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a structured dietary intervention could improve weight management in patients one year after Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significantly greater weight loss and reduced calorie intake compared to the control group at 4 and 6 months, though the calorie intake difference was only significant at 4 months.
population_specificity: Adults (average age 46.9) who underwent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery one year prior, predominantly female (85%) and White (80%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the challenges and outcomes of pregnancy following bariatric surgery, focusing on maternal and fetal risks, dumping syndromes, and nutritional management.
results_summary: The study found that while bariatric surgery improves fertility and reduces some adverse maternal and fetal outcomes in obese women, it poses risks such as intrauterine growth retardation and dumping syndromes. Dietary measures and pharmacotherapy (e.g., acarbose) are key for managing complications, and nutritional optimization is critical before and during pregnancy.
population_specificity: Women of childbearing age who have undergone bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the reliability of the phase angle (PhA) as a predictor of weight reduction and body composition after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found significant weight loss (30.1%) post-surgery, with PhA correlating significantly with excess weight loss (EWL) at multiple time points. A PhA of 3.9° was identified as the optimal cut-off for predicting successful outcomes.
population_specificity: 173 patients (127 with Roux-en-Y gastric bypass and 46 with sleeve gastrectomy) treated between 2004 and 2012.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential role of circadian system alterations in the metabolic benefits of bariatric surgery and identify possible mechanisms for its effectiveness.
results_summary: The study suggests bariatric surgery is highly effective for severe obesity, leading to significant weight loss and improvement in obesity-related comorbidities, possibly through changes in enteroendocrine activity, gut microbiota, and circadian clock alignment. It also highlights the potential for circadian system studies to uncover new behavioral interventions for metabolic outcomes post-surgery.
population_specificity: Individuals with severe obesity and related metabolic complications.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of bariatric surgery for severe obesity and related comorbidities.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery is the most effective long-term treatment for severe obesity and obesity-related comorbidities, with demonstrated cost-effectiveness and cost-savings in select patient subgroups. Despite these benefits, access to the treatment remains limited for eligible patients.
population_specificity: Patients with severe obesity and obesity-related comorbidities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of intragastric balloon (IGB) treatment for obesity by analyzing randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that IGB treatment, combined with lifestyle modification, was effective for short-term weight loss, with significant effect sizes of 1.59 and 1.34 kg/m². However, there was insufficient evidence to confirm its safety or long-term efficacy.
population_specificity: 1,195 patients across 20 randomized controlled trials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of various anti-reflux procedures in mitigating gastroesophageal reflux following sleeve gastrectomy.
results_summary: The study found that several anti-reflux techniques, including magnetic sphincter augmentation, radiofrequency ablation, and re-operation, can help manage reflux post-sleeve gastrectomy. Conversion to Roux-en-Y gastric bypass was identified as the only proven method for treating intractable reflux.
population_specificity: Individuals undergoing or considering bariatric surgery, particularly those with severe reflux.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the perioperative and early postoperative outcomes of mini-gastric bypass (MGB) and sleeve gastrectomy (SG) in super-obese patients.
results_summary: MGB achieved superior weight loss at 1 year and had a lower 30-day complication rate compared to SG in super-obese patients, suggesting MGB might be a better alternative for treating super-obesity.
population_specificity: Mostly super-obese patients (BMI ≥ 40 kg/m²) undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effectiveness of bariatric surgery as a therapeutic option for obese women with PCOS by examining its impact on gut-brain axis interactions and gastrointestinal hormones.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery, along with GLP-1 agonists, appears to be an effective therapeutic option for obese women with PCOS, significantly impacting the gut-brain axis and improving hormonal imbalances.
population_specificity: Obese women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of lifestyle-induced weight loss on serum bile acid composition and associated gut-derived hormone levels in individuals with metabolic syndrome, as a proxy for understanding metabolic improvements post-bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Lifestyle-induced weight loss improved insulin sensitivity, decreased serum bile acid species and total GLP-1 levels, and altered bile acid composition toward an increased 12α-hydroxylated/non-12α-hydroxylated ratio, while FGF-19 remained stable. No changes were observed in the control arm.
population_specificity: 74 non-smoking men aged 45-55 years with metabolic syndrome.
effective_dosage: Not specified (lifestyle-induced weight loss program supervised via telemonitoring).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of bariatric surgery in improving diabetic dyslipidemia and its role in managing cardiovascular risk factors in type 2 diabetes patients.
results_summary: The study suggests that bariatric surgery may improve diabetic dyslipidemia, but its cardiovascular benefits are not conclusively demonstrated. The abstract notes that significant residual risk remains despite current treatments, including bariatric surgery.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus and associated atherogenic risk factors (hypertriglyceridemia, low HDL-cholesterol, elevated LDL-cholesterol).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate quantitative and qualitative changes in platelet lineage (platelet count and mean platelet volume) following bariatric surgery in obese patients.
results_summary: The study found a significant decrease in platelet count and a non-significant decrease in mean platelet volume (MPV) 12 months after bariatric surgery. Sleeve gastrectomy (SG) caused a more significant reduction in platelet count than Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGBP), but MPV changes did not differ significantly between the two procedures.
population_specificity: 128 obese patients (mean age 43 ± 12 years, 77% female, mean BMI 44 ± 6 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety profile of bariatric surgery in patients with type 2 diabetes (T2D) and mild obesity (BMI ≥25 but <35 kg/m²).
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery was relatively well-tolerated in this population, with low rates of major complications (≤0.5%) except for postoperative bleeding (1.7%). Thirty-day morbidity and mortality rates were 4.2% and 0.15%, respectively, with no significant difference between Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) and sleeve gastrectomy (SG).
population_specificity: Patients with T2D and mild obesity (BMI ≥25 but <35 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of bariatric surgery on renal functions in patients with type 2 diabetes (T2D).
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was associated with significant improvements in albuminuria and urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio (uACR) but showed no statistically significant effects on glomerular filtration rate, serum creatinine, creatinine clearance, or end-stage renal disease risk. The evidence quality was deemed low, and further well-conducted trials are needed.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes (18,172 participants across 29 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the prognostic significance of eating pathology, as measured by the EDE-BSV, on long-term weight loss outcomes following bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that several forms of eating pathology declined significantly post-surgery, and higher postsurgery EDE global scores and hunger were associated with less weight loss, while cravings were linked to greater weight loss.
population_specificity: 183 participants from the Longitudinal Assessment of Bariatric Surgery (LABS) Research Consortium.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if the T allele of the FKBP5 SNP rs1360780 influences weight loss outcomes after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Carriers of the T allele showed significantly lower weight loss compared to those with the C/C genotype after 12-14 months, with differences ranging from 14.2% to 19.9% of excess weight loss. The T allele was also associated with earlier cessation of weight loss post-surgery.
population_specificity: 42 patients awaiting bariatric surgery at Hospital de Clínicas de Porto Alegre, Brazil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the rise in bariatric surgery and subsequent body contouring procedures, comparing trends between the United States and China.
results_summary: The study highlights the increase in bariatric surgery and associated body contouring procedures in the United States, with emerging techniques focusing on tissue preservation. It suggests China may adopt or refine these techniques as obesity rates rise.
population_specificity: General obesity trends in the United States and China, with a focus on post-bariatric surgery patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of bariatric surgery in treating type 2 diabetes (T2D) in morbidly obese patients.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery led to complete resolution of T2D in 78.1% of morbidly obese patients, demonstrating high efficacy for this population. The results highlight its potential as a treatment for obesity-related T2D.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients with BMI >35 kg/m² and type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the incidence, clinical presentation, management, and outcomes of thrombotic events following bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that thrombotic events, including PSMVT, were rare after bariatric surgery, with an incidence of 0.55% after LSG. Extended anticoagulation therapy significantly reduced thrombosis rates, and all cases resolved without sequelae or mortality.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent bariatric surgery (LSG, Roux-en-Y gastric bypass, adjustable gastric banding, or biliopancreatic diversion) at two university hospitals between 2006 and 2015.
effective_dosage: 40 mg enoxaparin daily, starting 12 hours after surgery until discharge; some patients received an extended course for 1-4 weeks post-discharge.
study_duration: Variable, from immediate post-surgery to 4 weeks post-discharge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, efficacy, and long-term outcomes of metabolic surgery (specifically Roux-en-Y gastric bypass and sleeve gastrectomy) for type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) patients with BMI ≤35 kg/m² and propose a Metabolic Risk Score for surgical indication.
results_summary: Metabolic surgery demonstrated similar safety and efficacy in T2DM patients with BMI ≤35 kg/m² compared to higher BMI groups, achieving superior glycemic control compared to clinical treatment and lifestyle changes, partly through weight-loss-independent mechanisms. Long-term success rates were not correlated with baseline BMI, and Roux-en-Y gastric bypass was the preferred technique, with sleeve gastrectomy as an alternative for contraindicated cases.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and BMI between 30 and 35 kg/m² who had inadequate clinical control.
study_duration: Long-term follow-up (specific duration not stated in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the contributions of calorie restriction, nutrient rerouting, and adipose tissue reduction to improved glucose metabolism after Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) in type 2 diabetes patients.
results_summary: The study found that RYGB improved whole-body insulin sensitivity and postprandial glucose response early after surgery, with further improvements at one year. Calorie restriction and nutrient rerouting contributed through distinct mechanisms, while weight loss enhanced insulin sensitivity via increased glucose oxidation and nonoxidative glucose disposal.
population_specificity: Fifteen diabetic patients (age 47±9 years, BMI 41.3±4.2 kg/m²).
study_duration: 2 weeks of very low-calorie diet (VLCD) pre-surgery, 2 weeks post-surgery, and 1-year follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the occurrence, risk factors, and management of portomesenteric vein thrombosis following laparoscopic bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that portomesenteric vein thrombosis is not uncommon after laparoscopic bariatric surgery, particularly after sleeve gastrectomy, and emphasized the need for early detection and extended thromboprophylaxis in high-risk patients.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent laparoscopic bariatric surgery (excluding gastric banding) and developed portomesenteric vein thrombosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of endogenous GLP-1 secretion restoration in the resolution of type 2 diabetes following bariatric surgery and compare its effects with GLP-1 receptor agonists.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery and GLP-1 receptor agonists improve type 2 diabetes differently, highlighting GLP-1's dual roles as a hormone and neurotransmitter. It suggested that postsurgical GLP-1 secretion may contribute to diabetes resolution.
population_specificity: Obese or overweight individuals with type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize and synthesize diverse health economic evaluations of bariatric surgery to inform healthcare resource allocation decisions.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery was cost-effective or cost-saving for severely obese individuals with type 2 diabetes mellitus, but identified gaps in evaluating broader societal costs (e.g., out-of-pocket expenses, productivity losses) and long-term outcomes (e.g., reoperations, complications). Study quality was inconsistent, with many omitting key cost factors.
population_specificity: Severely obese individuals, particularly those with type 2 diabetes mellitus, across 17 countries (56% USA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review obesity treatment options, including bariatric surgery, for patients who do not respond to lifestyle counseling.
results_summary: The abstract highlights bariatric surgery as an important escalation option for appropriate patients, but does not provide specific efficacy results. It positions surgery as part of a broader obesity management strategy.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity who do not respond to lifestyle interventions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG) and laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (LRYGB) in achieving HbA1c <6% without diabetes medication at 5 years in obese patients with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, but the abstract outlines the methodology and secondary outcomes, including weight loss, comorbidity reduction, and mechanistic insights into T2D remission. Final results will determine which surgery is more effective.
population_specificity: Obese patients (BMI 35-65 kg/m²) aged 20-55 with type 2 diabetes of at least 6 months duration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize evidence on the effectiveness, health benefits, risks, and patient experiences of weight management treatments, including bariatric surgery, to inform the development of a decision aid.
results_summary: Bariatric surgeries, such as RYGB and SG, were associated with greater weight loss and health benefits but also higher risks, complications, and financial costs compared to other treatments. Patient experiences with these options were mixed and not well understood.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18 years and over seeking weight management treatments at The Ottawa Hospital.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the current state of obesity care pathways in the UK, including the role of bariatric surgery within the 4-tier model.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the lack of a single stakeholder responsible for obesity care, inadequate service provision, and a "postcode lottery" in access to treatments like bariatric surgery, but does not report specific outcomes of the surgery itself.
population_specificity: General UK population with obesity, particularly those requiring severe and complex obesity management.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe Kaiser Permanente's "whole systems" approach to obesity management, including the role of bariatric surgery in treatment intensification.
results_summary: The abstract highlights Kaiser Permanente's standardized approach to obesity treatment, which includes bariatric surgery as an option for patients requiring intensified care, but does not provide specific outcomes or efficacy data for the surgery itself.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity, particularly those at high risk of diabetes and other weight-related conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a standardized system of bariatric care improved short- and long-term clinical outcomes for patients undergoing bariatric surgery in Ontario since 2010.
results_summary: The study found that standardization significantly reduced postoperative complication rates, maintained stable weight loss (33.2% at 1 year, 34.1% at 2 years, 32.7% at 3 years), and demonstrated sustained regression of obesity-related comorbidities. Thirty-day mortality was rare (<0.075%) and showed no significant variation over time.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery in Ontario between April 2010 and March 2015 (n=8,043).
study_duration: Follow-up periods of 1, 2, and 3 years post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess and characterize the impact of different types of bariatric surgery on obese patients with Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA).
results_summary: Bariatric surgery significantly improved AHI/AI/RDI and reduced BMI, with combined malabsorptive and restrictive procedures (e.g., RYGB) being more effective than purely restrictive ones (e.g., LAGB). Most studies reported postoperative AHI reduction to <20/h or >50% reduction, though results should be interpreted cautiously due to potential biases.
population_specificity: Obese patients with OSA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize surgical and radiologic findings of gastropericardial fistula cases, including those related to bariatric surgery, and present a diagnostic algorithm.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was identified as an etiology in 11% of gastropericardial fistula cases, with an average duration of 7.3 years between surgery and presentation. Radiology, particularly computed tomography, was crucial for diagnosis.
population_specificity: Patients with gastropericardial fistula, including those with prior bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of bariatric/metabolic surgery on blood pressure control and its broader effects on metabolic syndrome components.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric/metabolic surgery significantly improves or resolves hypertension in a notable proportion of patients, with growing evidence suggesting reduced incidence of cardiovascular events. However, most data on hypertension outcomes derive from secondary endpoints of trials.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity and hypertension, likely including those with metabolic syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how bariatric surgery affects oral drug absorption, review existing literature, and provide guidelines for post-surgery medication management.
results_summary: The study highlights that bariatric surgery can significantly alter oral drug absorption due to modified gastrointestinal anatomy, but current literature is insufficient, necessitating close patient monitoring for medication safety and efficacy post-surgery.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery, particularly those with severe obesity or obesity with comorbidities.
interactions: Altered absorption of oral medications post-surgery mentioned, but no specific interactions detailed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of conservative management for asymptomatic gallbladder disease in bariatric surgery candidates and assess the incidence of de novo gallbladder disease post-surgery.
results_summary: The study found that conservative management of asymptomatic gallbladder disease was safe, with only 3.4% of patients requiring cholecystectomy after 12 months. There was no difference in weight loss (%EWL) between patients with de novo gallbladder disease and those without.
population_specificity: Patients submitted to bariatric surgery from 2012 to 2014, predominantly female (81.1%) with a mean age of 38.5 years.

study_goal: To provide clinicians with a comprehensive overview of endoscopic treatments for obesity as an alternative to bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Endoscopic treatments for obesity show short-term promise, with intragastric balloons demonstrating 30%-50% excess weight loss after removal, though long-term outcomes remain unclear.
population_specificity: Not specified (general obesity population implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the proportion and clinical significance of findings from preoperative EGD in bariatric surgery patients to assess its necessity.
results_summary: The study found that preoperative EGD led to changes in surgical management in 7.8% of cases, but only 0.4% after excluding benign findings. Changes in medical management occurred in 27.5%, dropping to 2.5% after excluding H. pylori eradication.
population_specificity: Average-risk, asymptomatic bariatric surgery patients (mean age 40.5 years, BMI 46.3 kg/m², 77.1% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether baseline inflammatory gene expression in adipose tissue was associated with short-term remission of type 2 diabetes (T2D) after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that patients who still required metformin 3 months post-surgery had lower baseline inflammatory mRNA expression in subcutaneous adipose tissue (SAT) compared to those who did not. Higher TNF-α expression in SAT was associated with continued T2D treatment post-surgery.
population_specificity: 60 morbidly obese patients with T2D treated with metformin before bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of different treatment options for staple-line disruption (SLD) after laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG), with a focus on proximal gastrectomy with Roux-en-Y esophagojejunostomy (PGEJ).
results_summary: The study found that PGEJ had a high cure rate (94.7%) for SLD, while minor surgical procedures were effective in only 54.5% of cases. PGEJ was identified as a long-term solution for chronic leaks.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent LSG and experienced staple-line disruption between January 2005 and April 2014.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the limitations of current BMI-based criteria for bariatric surgery and advocate for updated guidelines to include metabolic benefits, particularly for patients with T2DM and lower BMIs.
results_summary: The study highlights that BMI alone is an inadequate criterion for bariatric surgery, potentially excluding patients who could benefit from the procedure. It calls for new guidelines to better regulate and reimburse metabolic surgery based on evidence from randomized controlled trials.
population_specificity: Severely obese patients and those with T2DM and lower BMIs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effectiveness of two physical activity interventions (pedometer use and exercise counseling plus pedometer) before and up to 6½ months after bariatric surgery compared to standard care.
results_summary: Exercise counseling plus pedometer use increased physical activity (steps per day and bout minutes of exercise per week) compared to standard care and pedometer use alone. All groups showed improved exercise tolerance, but no significant changes in sedentary or light activity were observed.
population_specificity: Individuals undergoing bariatric surgery.
study_duration: Approximately 6½ months (perioperative period to 6 months postoperatively)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of exaggerated GLP-1 secretion in the antidiabetic and anorectic effects of gastric bypass surgery and compare its mechanisms with other bariatric procedures.
results_summary: The study found that GLP-1 secretion significantly increases after gastric bypass, contributing to improved insulin secretion and glucose tolerance, but may also cause postprandial hypoglycemia. Other bariatric procedures, like biliopancreatic diversion and sleeve gastrectomy, appear to involve different mechanisms, and rodent models show increased energy metabolism, differing from human outcomes.
population_specificity: Humans and rodents (for experimental comparison)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the usefulness and limitations of the UK National Bariatric Surgery Registry (NBSR) in improving knowledge about metabolic and bariatric surgery, comparing baseline characteristics and outcomes with other registries.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery led to a 61.5% improvement in diabetes rates at 2 years, with variations based on diabetes duration and baseline therapy. The most common procedures were gastric bypass, gastric banding, and sleeve gastrectomy, with differences in prevalence between public and private sectors.
population_specificity: 32,212 anonymized patients (76% female, mean weight 135.6 kg, BMI 48.8 kg/m²) from 137 UK bariatric surgery units.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effectiveness of bariatric surgery for severe obesity in children and adolescents, highlighting those at risk and discussing referral, current services, and therapeutic interventions.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery is effective in exceptional cases for severe obesity in children and adolescents, while lifestyle interventions and pharmacotherapy have high relapse rates. It also noted a high incidence of cardiovascular risk factors in this population.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents in the UK with severe obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the impact of bariatric surgery on renal function and identify factors influencing glomerular filtration rate (GFR) changes post-surgery.
results_summary: GFR decreased after bariatric surgery in subjects with hyperfiltration but increased in those with renal failure. Changes in body mass, protein intake, and blood pressure were key determinants of GFR evolution post-surgery.
population_specificity: 323 patients (age 43 ± 11 years, M/F 49/274, BMI 46 ± 7 kg/m²) who underwent bariatric surgery between 2004 and 2014.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of the transversus abdominal plane (TAP) block in reducing postoperative pain and morphine consumption after bariatric surgery compared to placebo or other analgesic techniques.
results_summary: The study found that TAP block significantly reduced postoperative pain scores at 6, 12, and 24 hours and decreased 24-hour morphine consumption compared to placebo, though intrathecal morphine showed greater analgesic efficacy.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery among other abdominal surgeries (gynecological, appendectomy, inguinal, urological).
study_duration: Postoperative pain and morphine consumption assessed up to 24 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare calcium metabolism and weight outcomes in patients undergoing BPD versus those who underwent BPD followed by revisional surgery due to side effects or ineffectiveness.
results_summary: Revisional surgery improved calcium metabolism (reduced PTH, increased vitamin D and calcium levels) and further decreased weight, suggesting better control of malabsorption effects. Weight loss was inversely associated with vitamin D levels and directly associated with PTH changes.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing biliopancreatic diversion (BPD) with or without revisional surgery.
study_duration: 120 months (10 years) total observation period, with revisional surgery after a median of 48 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the incidence and mechanisms of orthostatic intolerance (OI) following bariatric surgery, particularly focusing on autonomic dysfunction and its implications for patient management.
results_summary: The study found that a significant proportion of post-bariatric surgery patients experienced orthostatic intolerance, with 35.7% meeting criteria for Postural Tachycardia Syndrome (PoTS), 57.1% having low basal BP, and 42.9% experiencing presyncope. The authors suggest that OI may be more common than previously recognized and that further research is needed to identify at-risk populations.
population_specificity: 14 patients with orthostatic intolerance post-bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the prevalence of vitamin D deficiency in bariatric surgery candidates and its potential impact on surgical outcomes, as well as the long-term metabolic complications of bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that over 50% of bariatric surgery candidates have vitamin D deficiency, which persists post-operatively and may contribute to adverse surgical outcomes like poor wound healing and infection. Obesity-related chronic inflammation combined with vitamin D deficiency likely exacerbates these risks, and correcting deficiency preoperatively could improve outcomes.
population_specificity: Obese individuals undergoing or considering bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate respiratory muscle strength in morbidly obese patients before and after bariatric surgery and compare these measurements with predictive values from different mathematical equations.
results_summary: The study found that preoperative maximal inspiratory pressure (MIP) predictions varied significantly across equations, with the Enright equation showing no significant difference. Postoperatively, MIP values diverged from predictions at 3 and 6 months, and all equations showed significant differences at 9 months. The Enright equation was deemed the most suitable for predicting MIP in this population.
population_specificity: 122 morbidly obese patients (104 women, 18 men) with a mean age of 43.02 ± 11.11 years and mean BMI of 43.10 ± 5.25 kg/m².
study_duration: 9 months (measurements at screening, 3, 6, and 9 months postoperative)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of bariatric surgery in treating type-2 diabetes and promoting weight loss in obese and borderline diabetic individuals.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was found to be highly effective in treating type-2 diabetes and achieving significant weight loss, with modifications of primary procedures improving efficacy. Good incretin responses and combined medical treatment contributed to long-term glycemic control.
population_specificity: Obese persons and borderline diabetics.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of bariatric surgery on obesity-related glomerulopathy, particularly its antiproteinuric effects and reversal of hyperfiltration.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery induced consistent and dramatic antiproteinuric effects and reversal of hyperfiltration, outperforming short-term renin-angiotensin-aldosterone blockade. The study also highlighted the role of altered lipid metabolism in renal damage and suggested potential new therapies targeting lipid pathways.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity-related glomerulopathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG) with conventional medical therapy (CMT) in obese patients newly diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results, as it describes the study's aim rather than its findings.
population_specificity: Obese patients (BMI 30–42 kg/m²) newly diagnosed with T2DM.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze whether metabolically healthy obese (MHO) individuals improve after interventions like bariatric surgery or maintain their health over time.
results_summary: The study found that MHO individuals exhibit unique protective factors reducing metabolic and cardiovascular risks despite obesity, but the abstract does not specify concrete outcomes of bariatric surgery for this population.
population_specificity: Metabolically healthy obese (MHO) individuals with long-standing or morbid obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term efficacy of Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) in weight loss, metabolic syndrome control, and type 2 diabetes (T2D) remission compared to medical therapy and other bariatric procedures.
results_summary: The study found that RYGB provides long-lasting benefits in weight loss and metabolic syndrome control, with significantly greater T2D remission and reduced cardiovascular and vascular complications compared to medical therapy. While T2D can relapse, the overall benefits of RYGB remain substantial, and it may outperform sleeve gastrectomy in improving glucose homeostasis.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity and type 2 diabetes (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the physiological and behavioral effects of bariatric surgery, particularly focusing on changes in taste perception and food preferences, as a treatment for obesity and type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that bariatric surgery provides durable weight loss and health benefits for obese patients with comorbidities like type 2 diabetes, but questions remain about metabolic mechanisms, predictors of success, and long-term consequences. Recent studies suggest that changes in taste and food preferences post-surgery may influence weight loss outcomes.
population_specificity: Obese patients with comorbidities such as type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the short- and long-term outcomes of bariatric surgery, focusing on the remission rates of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) in patients with early-onset (age <40 years) versus late-onset (age ≥40 years) T2DM.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery resulted in higher rates of T2DM remission and greater weight loss in patients with early-onset T2DM compared to those with late-onset T2DM, both at 1-year and 5-year follow-ups. Age at surgery, duration of T2DM, and preoperative C-peptide levels were independent predictors of remission.
population_specificity: 558 Taiwanese patients (339 with early-onset T2DM, 219 with late-onset T2DM) with a BMI above 25.
study_duration: Follow-up for at least 1 year, with some data extending to 5 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and safety of laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB), sleeve gastrectomy (LSG), and adjustable gastric banding (LAGB) in a publicly funded bariatric treatment program.
results_summary: RYGB and LSG resulted in significantly greater weight loss and reduction in obesity-related comorbidities compared to LAGB. All procedures were found to be safe, with no deaths and a low rate of complications.
population_specificity: 150 consecutive bariatric surgery patients (87.3% women, mean age 43.5 ± 9.5 years, mean BMI 46.2 ± 7.4) in a publicly funded Canadian program.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a case of biliary ileus after bariatric surgery and review existing literature on this rare complication.
results_summary: The study identified a case of gallstone ileus eight years post-bariatric surgery, diagnosed via CT and ultrasound, and treated laparoscopically. It also reviewed three similar cases from literature, highlighting diagnostic and surgical considerations.
population_specificity: A 41-year-old patient with prior biliointestinal bypass for morbid obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the mechanisms, indications, and benefits of bariatric surgery in reducing cardiovascular disease (CVD) and improving obesity-related comorbidities.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery effectively reduces obesity-related comorbidities, improves quality of life, and lowers all-cause mortality, with less invasive procedures offering lower risks but also less weight loss. The rationale for CVD risk reduction was supported by improvements in risk factors like dyslipidemia, hypertension, and diabetes.
population_specificity: Patients with severe obesity who were unable to sustain weight loss through nonsurgical means.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the outcomes and complications of bariatric surgery in adolescents with type 2 diabetes and provide recommendations for future research and refinement of its use.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that bariatric surgery may improve or induce remission of type 2 diabetes in adolescents, similar to outcomes observed in adults, but also discusses associated complications and the need for further research.
population_specificity: Obese adolescents with type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how altered adipose tissue physiology contributes to the metabolic effects of bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery produces significant weight loss, improves insulin sensitivity, and enhances metabolic function by shifting fat distribution, improving lipolysis sensitivity, altering adipokine secretion, and reducing inflammation, some of which are weight-loss independent.
population_specificity: Not specified (general obesity population implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical and nutritional outcomes of BPD-DS with a 200-cm common channel versus the standard 100-cm common channel in morbidly obese patients.
results_summary: The study found that BPD-DS with a 200-cm common channel had similar co-morbidity remission rates and weight loss at nadir but a lower incidence of severe protein deficiency, hyperparathyroidism, and fewer bowel movements compared to the standard 100-cm channel. However, weight regain was more significant in the 200-cm group.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients (mean BMI ~49-50 kg/m², 50% women) at a university-affiliated tertiary care center.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of bariatric/metabolic surgery for treating type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM), particularly in patients with a BMI <35 kg/m².
results_summary: The study found that bariatric/metabolic surgery is superior to medical/lifestyle interventions for T2DM remission, glycemic control, and HbA1c lowering, regardless of baseline BMI. Safety and benefits on cardiovascular risk factors were comparable across BMI thresholds.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus, including those with BMI below or above 35 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide a conceptual understanding of obesity and a rational approach to its treatment, highlighting its impact on women's reproductive health and future generations.
results_summary: The abstract does not present specific findings about Bariatric Surgery but emphasizes the growing concern of obesity in women and its broader public health implications.
population_specificity: Women, particularly concerning reproductive health and metabolic impacts on future generations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term effectiveness and safety of bariatric/metabolic surgery for treating morbid obesity and related diseases, as well as indications for revisional surgery.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery is the most effective long-term treatment for morbid obesity and related conditions, significantly reducing diabetes and cancer incidence and prolonging life compared to non-surgical therapies. However, it noted potential long-term complications like nutritional deficiencies and the need for complex revisional surgery in some cases.
population_specificity: Individuals with morbid obesity and obesity-related diseases (e.g., diabetes, heart disease, hypertension).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how frequently preoperative endoscopy (EGD) changes management in patients undergoing bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that preoperative EGD altered, delayed, or canceled surgery in a subset of patients, suggesting a selective approach based on symptoms, risk factors, and procedure type may be appropriate. The majority of patients had findings that did not significantly change management.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery (mean age 41.4 years, majority women, mean BMI 47 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the weight loss-independent antidiabetic effects of gastrointestinal surgery and challenge outdated BMI-centric eligibility criteria for metabolic surgery in T2D treatment.
results_summary: The study found strong evidence for weight loss-independent antidiabetic effects of gastrointestinal surgery, with metabolic outcomes unrelated to baseline BMI. Updated guidelines now prioritize T2D severity and control over BMI as the sole criterion for surgery eligibility.
population_specificity: Individuals with Type 2 Diabetes (T2D), with obesity as a qualifier but not the sole criterion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the remission of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) between laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG) and laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (LRYGB) and analyze their cost-effectiveness in patients with BMI ≥ 28.
results_summary: Both LSG and LRYGB significantly reduced fasting plasma glucose (FPG), hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c), and body weight in T2DM patients. LSG was found to be more cost-effective than LRYGB and medical treatment, with cost-effectiveness ratios of $1028.97, $1197.44, and $1589.02 per QALY, respectively.
population_specificity: 80 patients aged 16-65 years with BMI ≥ 28 kg/m² and T2DM duration ≤ 15 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare major surgical complications and 30-day mortality rates between laparoscopic and open Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (LRYGB and RYGB) and evaluate changes in outcomes over time.
results_summary: The study found a significantly higher mortality rate for open surgery (0.82%) compared to laparoscopic surgery (0.22%), with progressive declines in postoperative complications over time. Laparoscopic bariatric surgery was identified as the preferred approach due to lower mortality and complication rates.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery for morbid obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical outcomes, including weight loss and comorbidity resolution, of three bariatric procedures (LAGB, RYGB, and SG) in morbidly obese Korean adults.
results_summary: The three procedures showed similar weight-loss outcomes at 18 months, but RYGB had higher rates of comorbidity resolution. Safety profiles were similar, though complications occurred, including band removals in LAGB and a death in RYGB.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese Korean adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether GLP-1 acts through endocrine mechanisms in bariatric surgery patients and how it impacts glucose regulation post-surgery.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery (gastric bypass and sleeve gastrectomy) significantly increases postprandial GLP-1 release, leading to improved glucose regulation. Interference with GLP-1 receptor signaling post-surgery notably affects glucose control, suggesting an endocrine role for GLP-1 in these conditions.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery (gastric bypass or sleeve gastrectomy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term clinical outcomes of bariatric surgery, particularly its effects on microvascular and macrovascular complications in diabetic patients, compared to intensive medical therapy.
results_summary: The study found insufficient evidence to determine whether bariatric surgery reduces long-term microvascular and macrovascular complications compared to intensive glycemic control, but noted consistent benefits in diabetes remission and glycemic improvement, highlighting the need for high-quality comparative studies.
population_specificity: Patients with diabetes who underwent bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of three video laryngoscope devices versus standard direct laryngoscopy for tracheal intubation in obese patients undergoing bariatric surgery.
results_summary: All three video laryngoscope devices improved glottic views compared to standard direct laryngoscopy, with Video-Mac and McGrath reducing the time to obtain a glottic view. Video-Mac also reduced tracheal tube placement time and required fewer intubation attempts compared to other methods.
population_specificity: Obese patients (BMI >30 kg/m²), aged 18-80 years, ASA physical status I-III, undergoing elective bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of psychosocial factors in long-term outcomes of bariatric surgery and outline recommendations for psychosocial evaluation and behavioral healthcare.
results_summary: The study highlights the importance of psychosocial factors in emotional adjustment, adherence to postoperative regimens, weight loss outcomes, and comorbidity resolution, recommending specialized behavioral health involvement before and after surgery.
population_specificity: Bariatric surgery patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the pathophysiological and clinical relationship between obesity and lower limb venous disease, including the role of bariatric surgery in management.
results_summary: The study found that obesity is a significant risk factor for lower limb venous disease, but the evidence base for treatments like bariatric surgery in obese patients is limited and may be associated with worse outcomes compared to non-obese patients.
population_specificity: Obese individuals with or at risk of lower limb venous disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare postoperative pain reduction in laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy patients using intravenous analgesia alone versus combined with epidural analgesia or port-sites infiltration with bupivacaine.
results_summary: Both epidural analgesia and port-sites infiltration with bupivacaine, when combined with intravenous analgesia, significantly reduced postoperative pain and morphine rescue needs compared to intravenous analgesia alone, with no significant differences between the two combined methods.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy between 2012 and 2014.
study_duration: Pain and morphine rescue needs were assessed 24 hours after surgery.

study_goal: To determine the effect of an additional intervention (letter to patients and GPs) compared to care-as-usual on reducing NSAID use post-bariatric surgery and to assess PPI use in NSAID users.
results_summary: The intervention did not significantly reduce NSAID use (22% to 18% in intervention vs. 20% to 21% in control). PPI use with NSAIDs increased slightly in the intervention group (52% to 55%) and more in the control group (52% to 69%), but neither change was statistically significant.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent bariatric surgery (n=248, split into intervention and control groups).
study_duration: Data collected from 3 to 9 months post-intervention.
interactions: NSAIDs and PPIs mentioned, but no specific interactions detailed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether CPAP improves postoperative oxygenation, mitigates opioid-induced respiratory depression, and reduces sleep-disordered breathing (SDB) in bariatric surgery patients.
results_summary: CPAP treatment significantly reduced the apnea hypopnea index (AHI), decreased oxygen desaturations, and improved mean oxygen saturation by 3%. It also mitigated opioid-induced respiratory depression without affecting hemodynamics.
population_specificity: Post-bariatric surgery patients in the postanesthesia care unit (PACU).
interactions: Opioids (significant interaction effects noted with CPAP for AHI, inspiratory flow, and minute ventilation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the surgical options for managing obesity in patients with Barrett's esophagus, focusing on the comparative effectiveness of gastric bypass and sleeve gastrectomy.
results_summary: The majority of authors concluded that gastric bypass is the preferred procedure for obese patients with Barrett's esophagus, while sleeve gastrectomy is not an absolute contraindication. Further research is needed to establish a definitive consensus.
population_specificity: Obese patients with Barrett's esophagus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess maternal and fetal outcomes in pregnancies complicated by internal herniation after Roux-en-Y gastric bypass.
results_summary: Internal herniation after Roux-en-Y gastric bypass typically presents with subtle signs in the third trimester, often requiring surgical intervention. Delayed treatment (>48 hours) was associated with severe adverse outcomes, including maternal and perinatal deaths.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with a history of Roux-en-Y gastric bypass who experienced internal herniation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of bariatric surgery on lung age (LA) in morbidly obese patients and assess whether functional pulmonary rejuvenation occurred post-surgery.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in spirometric variables (FVC, FEV1, FEV1/FVC ratio) and a reduction in lung age by 11.90 years post-surgery, indicating functional pulmonary rejuvenation. The difference between lung age and chronological age normalized after surgery, suggesting reversal of accelerated pulmonary aging caused by obesity.
population_specificity: 43 morbidly obese patients who underwent bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the longitudinal effects of biliointestinal bypass (BIBP) on glycemic control in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2D).
results_summary: BIBP significantly improved fasting glycemia, insulinemia, and glycosylated hemoglobin levels over 2 years, with 83% of patients discontinuing medical therapy and the remaining 17% reducing therapy to oral hypoglycemic agents. The procedure demonstrated favorable metabolic effects and a positive risk-benefit relationship in the short term.
population_specificity: 28 consecutive patients with T2D from university hospitals in Europe and Canada.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the outcomes and complications of various surgical revision methods after failed Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) to identify the option with the best outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that BPD/DS, DRYGB, and gastric banding resulted in sustained weight loss with acceptable complication rates, while gastric pouch/anastomosis revision had the lowest major complication rate. Endoluminal procedures showed the least efficacy in weight loss.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent revisional surgery for weight regain after failed RYGB (866 patients across 24 studies).
study_duration: Follow-up periods of up to 1 and 3 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the effects of substantial weight loss from bariatric surgery on rheumatic disease outcomes and to highlight important considerations for rheumatologists regarding nutritional deficiencies and medication restrictions in this patient population.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery leads to substantial and sustained weight loss, which may improve rheumatic disease outcomes. It also emphasized the need for rheumatologists to understand common bariatric procedures and associated nutritional and medication considerations.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese adults in the United States, particularly those with rheumatic conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) surgery versus medical treatment alone for achieving remission of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) in obese patients.
results_summary: RYGB surgery was significantly more effective than medical treatment alone in achieving T2DM remission, improving metabolic conditions, and reducing cardiovascular risk factors, though nutritional deficiencies and anemia were more frequent in the surgical group.
population_specificity: Obese patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of incretins, particularly GLP-1 and DPP-4, in obesity pathogenesis and how bariatric surgery leverages this system for weight loss and diabetes management.
results_summary: The study highlights that bariatric surgery's high weight loss efficacy is linked to the incretin system, particularly GLP-1's role in appetite suppression and gastric emptying. It also suggests that DPP-4's involvement in adipose tissue inflammation provides a pathophysiological basis for obesity-related complications.
population_specificity: Obese individuals, often with associated diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether bariatric surgery before total hip arthroplasty (THA) reduces dislocation risk in obese patients and whether dual-mobility or constrained liners are more effective in preventing dislocation.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery reduced BMI but did not decrease dislocation risk with standard liners. Dual-mobility or constrained liners effectively reduced dislocation risk in obese patients.
population_specificity: Obese patients (BMI > 30 kg/m²) undergoing THA, including those with prior bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of Adapted Motivational Interviewing (AMI) on patients' readiness for change, self-efficacy, and adherence to dietary guidelines following bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that AMI improved readiness, confidence, and self-efficacy for change immediately post-intervention, with additional improvements in binge eating symptomatology and dietary adherence over 12 weeks. The AMI group showed significant improvements in these outcomes compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Post-operative bariatric patients (N=51).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the emerging focus of research evidence on medical tourism, including bariatric surgery, post-2010, covering definitions, consumer choice, clinical quality, outcomes, and health system implications.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings on bariatric surgery's effects but highlights gaps in research evidence related to medical tourism, including clinical quality and outcomes.
population_specificity: Consumers electing to travel across borders or overseas for medical treatments, including bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review current and emerging endoscopic bariatric therapies, focusing on procedural techniques and available evidence for treating obesity.
results_summary: The study highlights that endoscopic bariatric therapies, such as intragastric balloons and endoscopic sleeve gastroplasty, show potential for reducing adverse events, cost, and recovery times compared to surgical approaches. These techniques are presented as viable alternatives or adjuncts to traditional bariatric surgery.
population_specificity: Patients with a BMI range of 30-40 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine postoperative eating behaviors and weight control practices and their impact on 3-year weight change following bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that positive postoperative behaviors, such as weekly self-weighing and avoiding overeating, were associated with significantly greater weight loss (up to 14% more) compared to those who made no positive changes. Participants who adopted healthy behaviors post-surgery lost an average of 38.8% of their baseline weight over three years.
population_specificity: Adults with severe obesity (median BMI 46) undergoing first-time bariatric surgery, predominantly women (78%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of autologous intestinal reconstruction (AIR) techniques, such as LILT, STEP, and SILT, in treating short bowel syndrome (SBS) before considering intestinal transplantation (ITx).
results_summary: The study found that LILT and STEP are effective in AIR, with STEP showing similar success rates to LILT and fewer patients progressing to ITx. SILT was noted as a promising alternative, but further research is needed to confirm its efficacy.
population_specificity: Patients with short bowel syndrome (SBS) and life-threatening complications where parenteral nutrition has failed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the incidence of intraoperative staple line leaks and bleeds during laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG) and laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (LRYGB).
results_summary: The study found that LSG had intraoperative leaks and bleeds as high as 3.93% and 4.07%, respectively, while LRYGB had leaks in up to 8.26% and bleeds in 3.45% of cases. Stapler misfire was a common cause, and the incidence may be underestimated due to underreporting and lack of standardized testing.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing LSG or LRYGB (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the current state of anti-obesity pharmacotherapy and highlight the potential of natural compounds as candidates for drug development, given the limitations of existing treatments like bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results on bariatric surgery but highlights the lack of efficient and safe drugs for obesity treatment, suggesting that natural compounds may offer promising alternatives.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion on obesity treatment)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the current state and recent trends in endoscopic weight loss procedures as an alternative to bariatric surgery for obesity management.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that bariatric surgery is the most effective weight loss treatment but has risks, costs, and limited applicability. Endoscopic procedures show promise as less invasive, reversible, and cost-effective alternatives, though long-term safety and efficacy data are still needed.
population_specificity: Not specified (general obesity population implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether surgical skill levels of bariatric surgeons influence long-term outcomes (weight loss and comorbidity resolution) after laparoscopic gastric bypass.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in excess body weight loss or resolution of comorbidities (hypertension, sleep apnea, hyperlipidemia) between the highest and lowest skill quartiles of surgeons. However, patients of lower-skilled surgeons had higher diabetes resolution rates (78.8% vs. 72.8%).
population_specificity: 3,631 patients undergoing bariatric surgery by 20 surgeons in Michigan hospitals (2006–2012).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how bariatric surgery alters the gut microbiota and its potential role in metabolic improvements, such as weight loss and diabetes remission.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery alters the gut microbiota in both mice and humans, and transferring the post-surgery microbiota to mice demonstrated improved metabolic phenotypes, suggesting a causal link between microbiota changes and metabolic benefits. Reduced levels of butyrate-producing bacteria were linked to type 2 diabetes, while increased Lactobacillus sp. levels were observed in diabetic patients.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity and type 2 diabetes, as well as mice models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the clinical presentation, management, and outcomes of rare cases of porto-mesenteric venous thrombosis (PMVT) following laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG).
results_summary: Three patients developed PMVT post-LSG, presenting with abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. Two were treated conservatively with anticoagulation and thrombolytic therapy, while one required surgical intervention.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG) and developed PMVT.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of bariatric surgery on NAFLD/NASH remission, fibrosis regression, and overall mortality reduction.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was associated with decreased cardiovascular risk, improved overall mortality, and reduction in hepatic steatosis, inflammation, and fibrosis. Weight reductions of 7% to 10% were linked to NAFLD/NASH remission and fibrosis regression.
population_specificity: Individuals with NAFLD/NASH, likely those with metabolic syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of intravenous iron supplementation versus oral iron in treating anemia and preventing iron deficiency in women undergoing post-bariatric abdominoplasty.
results_summary: The study compared intravenous iron saccharate (two 200 mg doses) with oral iron polymaltose (100 mg twice daily for 8 weeks), measuring hemoglobin levels and iron profiles. Secondary outcomes included quality of life, fatigue, and adverse effects, but specific results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Adult women undergoing post-bariatric anchor-line abdominoplasty.
effective_dosage: Intravenous iron saccharate (200 mg, two applications) or oral iron polymaltose (100 mg twice daily).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the long-term metabolic and physiological effects of Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) surgery on pancreatic function, insulin sensitivity, and gastrointestinal remodeling.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery provides short-term diabetes remission in over 70% of cases and highlighted its striking acute metabolic effects, while emphasizing the need to understand long-term outcomes.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity and type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the lipid effects of bariatric procedures and their impact on cardiovascular risk factors, including nutrient absorption, gut hormones, and potential deficiencies.
results_summary: Bariatric procedures generally improve dyslipidemia and other major cardiovascular risk factors, with effects linked to changes in adipose tissue, bile acids, intestinal microbiota, and nutrient absorption. The study also reviews potential deficiencies post-surgery.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on patients undergoing bariatric procedures)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal pharmacologic prophylaxis (enoxaparin dosage) with minimal bleeding complications for bariatric surgery patients.
results_summary: The study found no thromboembolic complications, with the lowest bleeding risk in the low-dose enoxaparin group (40 mg once daily). Hypertension significantly increased bleeding risk.
population_specificity: 400 consecutive bariatric surgery patients (sleeve gastrectomy or Roux-en-Y gastric bypass) treated between 2008-2013 at Peijas Hospital.
effective_dosage: High-dose (40 mg twice daily), intermediate-dose (40 mg twice daily, skipping morning dose), low-dose (40 mg once daily, skipping morning dose).
study_duration: Intervention started 1 day before surgery; exact postoperative duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review definitions, rates, and causes of weight regain in patients at least 2 years post-sleeve gastrectomy (SG).
results_summary: The study found varying definitions and rates of weight regain (5.7% at 2 years to 75.6% at 6 years), with causes including sleeve size, dilation, ghrelin levels, follow-up support, and lifestyle behaviors. Standardization of definitions and larger prospective studies were recommended.
population_specificity: Patients at least 2 years post-sleeve gastrectomy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the current state of endoscopic bariatric devices as potential alternatives or bridges to bariatric surgery for obesity treatment.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that bariatric surgery is the gold standard for long-term obesity weight loss but is underutilized, and endoscopic treatments offer a cost-effective, minimally invasive alternative. It reviews various FDA-approved and developmental endoscopic devices for obesity management.
population_specificity: Obese patients worldwide (general population, no specific subgroup mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of vagal nerve blockade (vBloc) therapy in patients with moderate obesity (BMI 35-40 kg/m²) and related comorbidities.
results_summary: The vBloc group achieved significantly greater weight loss (33% EWL, 11% TWL) compared to the sham group (19% EWL, 6% TWL) at 12 months, with common adverse events being mild or moderate heartburn/dyspepsia and implant site pain.
population_specificity: Patients with moderate obesity (BMI 35-40 kg/m²) and at least one obesity-related comorbidity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate changes in pain and physical function over three years following bariatric surgery (RYGB or LAGB) and identify factors associated with improvement.
results_summary: A large percentage of participants experienced clinically meaningful improvements in pain, physical function, and walk time within the first year, though improvements in pain and physical function declined by year 3. Younger age, male sex, lower BMI, and fewer depressive symptoms were associated with better outcomes.
population_specificity: Adults with severe obesity (median BMI 45.9) undergoing bariatric surgery, predominantly women (78.5%), median age 47 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the current evidence for bariatric surgery, particularly gastric banding, as a treatment for severe and complex obesity, and to identify gaps in comparative effectiveness research.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery offers significant and durable weight loss for severe obesity, with three procedures accounting for 95% of UK surgeries, but noted a lack of high-quality comparative evidence. It highlighted the potential of gastric banding as lower-risk and lower-cost, while emphasizing the need for better RCT data to determine the best surgical option.
population_specificity: Individuals with severe and complex obesity in the UK, particularly those meeting NICE guidelines for bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the prevalence, risks, and monitoring recommendations for copper deficiency in patients undergoing Roux-en-Y gastric bypass.
results_summary: The study found that copper deficiency is common in bariatric surgery patients and can worsen after Roux-en-Y gastric bypass, potentially leading to neurological disability. However, adequately supplemented patients rarely develop deficiency, and routine monitoring may not be justified for asymptomatic individuals, though high-risk groups may still require screening.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing or having undergone Roux-en-Y gastric bypass.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine vitamin D status (serum 25[OH]D concentrations) before and after bariatric surgery and evaluate current supplementation regimens for addressing vitamin D deficiency and insufficiency in bariatric patients.
results_summary: Preoperative vitamin D deficiency (VDD) and insufficiency (VDI) were highly prevalent, with VDD ranging from 13% to 90% and VDI up to 98%. Postoperative prevalence remained similar, especially after RYGB. Most studies found dosages below 800 IU daily insufficient, while higher dosages (1000–5000 IU daily or 50,000 IU weekly plus daily doses) showed some effectiveness but failed to universally optimize serum 25(OH)D levels above 30 ng/mL.
population_specificity: Bariatric surgery patients (primarily Roux-en-Y gastric bypass [RYGB] and vertical sleeve gastrectomy [VSG] recipients).
effective_dosage: 800–5000 IU daily or 50,000 IU weekly plus daily doses.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore disparities in obesity treatment responses, including bariatric surgery, across different racial/ethnic and social groups, and identify potential reasons for differential outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that African Americans tend to lose less weight in clinical trials compared to non-Hispanic whites, with most evidence focused on behavioral interventions. It highlights the need for broader research on disparities in medical and surgical obesity treatments and potential physiologic drivers of differential responses.
population_specificity: Racial/ethnic groups (primarily African Americans and non-Hispanic whites) and other social/demographic subgroups with obesity disparities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of bariatric surgery as a treatment for obesity and its potential benefits for obesity-related gastrointestinal and liver diseases in Asia.
results_summary: The study found strong consensus (93.8% agreement) that bariatric surgery is an effective treatment for obesity, but there was less agreement (62.5%) on its benefits for non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
population_specificity: Asian population with obesity and related gastrointestinal/liver diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether routine intraoperative leak testing (IOLT) during sleeve gastrectomy (SG) reduces postoperative staple line leaks or provides actionable information.
results_summary: The study found that IOLT did not identify any staple line defects or predict postoperative leaks, and all patients who developed leaks had undergone IOLT. Routine IOLT was associated with a non-significantly higher leak rate (2.6% vs. 0%) compared to no IOLT.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing sleeve gastrectomy between 2007 and 2014 (n = 542).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review perioperative care for obese pediatric patients, including drug dosing challenges and recent outcomes of bariatric surgery in adolescents.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery in adolescents has shifted from roux-en-Y to sleeve gastrectomy with comparable results, and it is an effective intervention for severe obesity. High-risk children require special perioperative attention.
population_specificity: Adolescents with severe obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of bile acids (BAs) in mediating the metabolic benefits of bariatric surgery, particularly in glucose normalization and remission of type 2 diabetes (T2D).
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery effectively leads to glucose normalization and T2D remission, with bile acids (BAs) identified as key mediators of these effects through their interaction with the farnesoid X receptor (FXR) and regulation of genes involved in inflammation, obesity, and lipid metabolism.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract mentions clinical studies and animal models).

study_goal: To examine the efficacy of a pre-operative telephone-based cognitive behavioural therapy (Tele-CBT) intervention versus standard pre-operative care for improving eating psychopathology and psychosocial functioning in bariatric surgery candidates.
results_summary: The Tele-CBT group showed significant improvements in binge eating, emotional eating, and depression scores, while the standard care group reported worsening scores in emotional eating, depression, and anxiety. Tele-CBT appears effective for improving eating psychopathology and depression in bariatric surgery candidates.
population_specificity: Preoperative bariatric surgery patients (N = 47).
study_duration: Not specified (intervention duration implied by session count).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the cost, time commitment, and clinical outcomes of transitioning from laparoscopic (LRYGB) to robotic (RRYGB) gastric bypass procedures in an academic setting.
results_summary: The study found that both RRYGB and LRYGB had similar safety profiles and weight loss outcomes, but RRYGB initially required longer operative times and higher hospital costs, though operative time decreased after the first 10 cases.
population_specificity: Adults with a mean BMI of ~45-46 kg/m² undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) versus an intensive lifestyle and medical intervention (ILMI) for type 2 diabetes remission, including among patients with a BMI <35 kg/m².
results_summary: RYGB resulted in significantly greater weight loss (25.8% vs. 6.4%) and higher diabetes remission rates (60.0% vs. 5.9%) compared to ILMI at 1 year, with no life-threatening complications reported. The HbA1c decline was modestly greater with RYGB, but this occurred with fewer or no diabetes medications.
population_specificity: Adults aged 25-64 with type 2 diabetes and a BMI of 30-45 kg/m².
effective_dosage: Not applicable (surgical intervention vs. ILMI protocol).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of different bariatric surgery procedures (RYGB, LAGB, SG) in treating GERD and Barrett's esophagus in obese patients.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery significantly improves GERD symptoms, with RYGB showing the greatest effect. Hernia recurrence remains high in obese patients regardless of surgical approach, and limited data exists on Barrett's esophagus progression/regression post-surgery.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients with GERD and/or Barrett's esophagus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of bariatric surgery in managing metabolic complications associated with PCOS, particularly in cases resistant to lifestyle interventions.
results_summary: The abstract suggests bariatric surgery may be considered for resistant metabolic disease in PCOS, but does not provide specific outcomes or data on its effectiveness. It highlights the need for further research on comparative efficacy of interventions.
population_specificity: Women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) and associated metabolic complications.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether serum PCB concentrations during and after weight loss (via lifestyle counseling or bariatric surgery) were related to metabolic health outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that serum PCB concentrations were higher in metabolically unhealthy obese individuals at baseline but did not differ in their percentage increase post-intervention. PCB concentrations did not predict metabolic health improvements after weight loss.
population_specificity: 184 overweight and obese subjects, categorized as metabolically healthy or unhealthy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether altered bone turnover after bariatric surgery is due to metabolic consequences of the procedure itself or weight loss.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery resulted in a significantly greater decrease in BMI compared to lifestyle intervention and markedly increased bone turnover, which was correlated with BMI changes. The study found that the surgical procedure and changes in Wnt antagonists (dickkopf-1 and sclerostin) contributed to increased bone turnover.
population_specificity: Adults with obesity (n=74 for surgery, n=63 for lifestyle intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand how primary care physicians (PCPs) make decisions regarding severe obesity treatment and bariatric surgery referral.
results_summary: The study identified four treatment prioritization approaches by PCPs, with only one emphasizing obesity treatment. Five factors caused hesitation in referring patients for bariatric surgery, including concerns about long-term effectiveness and insurance coverage.
population_specificity: Primary care physicians practicing in small, medium, and large cities in Wisconsin.

study_goal: To assess the effectiveness and tolerability of perioperative noninvasive ventilation (NIV) in obese patients undergoing general anesthesia.
results_summary: NIV significantly improved oxygenation before and after general anesthesia, reduced respiratory complications, but did not significantly affect reintubation or unplanned ICU admission. NIV was well tolerated, with complications mainly due to intolerance (7%-28% of cases).
population_specificity: Obese adults (BMI ≥35 kg/m²) undergoing general anesthesia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the impact of 30-day versus 90-day postoperative PPI regimens on the incidence of marginal ulceration after LRYGB.
results_summary: The study found that a 90-day PPI regimen significantly reduced the incidence of marginal ulceration (6.5%) compared to a 30-day regimen (12.4%). The results were statistically significant (P<.05).
population_specificity: Patients undergoing LRYGB at a high-volume bariatric center in Hamilton, Ontario, Canada.
effective_dosage: Daily PPI therapy (specific dosage not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of different ventilation strategies for obese patients undergoing bariatric surgery.
